trans-unit.source:
References

  • https://datadetoxkit.org/en/home/
  • https://www.experian.com/blogs/ask-experian/how-do-you-protect-your-personal-information-online/
  • https://help.unhcr.org/czech/safe-online/
  • https://www.experian.com/blogs/ask-experian/how-do-you-protect-your-personal-information-online/
  • https://www.staysafeonline.org/
  • https://datadetoxkit.org/en/home https://help.unhcr.org/czech/safe-online/
  • https://safety.google/
  • [embed]https://www.facebook.com/privacy/guide[/embed]
  • https://tineye.com/
  • https://www.gasa.org/post/defending-against-scam-psychology
  • https://www.experian.com/blogs/ask-experian/how-do-you-protect-your-personal-information-online/
  • https://home.army.mil/belvoir/about/Garrison/public-affairs/digital-belvoir-eagle/decoding-scams-how-emotional-manipulation-makes-you-target
  • https://www.elevationfinancial.com/how-to-recognize-and-avoid-scams
  • https://www.canadianfinancialcrimeacademy.ca/financial-crime-articles/the-psychological-tactics-behind-fraud-how-scammers-exploit-human-behavior
  • https://www.scamwatch.gov.au/types-of-scams
  • https://controlaudits.com/blog/what-are-the-security-risks-and-solutions-for-online-learning-platforms/
  • https://www.aitimejournal.com/cybersecurity-risks-in-elearning-everything-you-should-know/42280/
  • https://www.isaca.org/resources/news-and-trends/isaca-now-blog/2022/online-education-from-a-security-risk-and-controls-perspective

Glossary

  • Audit controls – Tools or features that allow you to see who accessed your data, when, and what they did with it.
  • Clickbait – Sensational or misleading headlines designed to attract clicks.
  • Credential stuffing – An attack where stolen usernames and passwords from one site are used to break into accounts on other sites.
  • Cyberbullying – When someone uses the internet, social media, or digital devices to hurt, threaten, or embarrass another person through messages, photos, videos, or comments.
  • Data breach – A security incident where personal data is accidentally or unlawfully accessed, stolen, or exposed.
  • Deepfake – Artificial intelligence technology that creates fake videos or audio of people saying or doing things they never did.
  • Digital footprint – All the information about you that exists online, including posts, photos, comments, and anything else people can find.
  • Disinformation – False information deliberately created and spread to mislead or harm people.
  • Echo chamber – A situation where someone only sees opinions that match their own, limiting exposure to other perspectives.
  • Emotional bait – A message or post designed to trigger strong emotions (fear, love, hope, urgency) to make someone act quickly without thinking.
  • Emotional manipulation (emotional trap) – Using feelings (love, fear, urgency, sympathy) to make someone act without thinking, often to share data or money.
  • Fake diploma – A certificate that looks official but is not recognized or valid, often sold by fraudulent websites.
  • Fake profile – An online profile created by someone pretending to be another person, often using stolen photos or false details, to gain trust and misuse information.
  • Google Safe Browsing – A free tool by Google that checks if a website is dangerous or known for scams.
  • Hoax – A deliberate lie or prank spread to confuse or entertain people.
  • HTTPS encryption – A security feature that protects the data sent between your browser and a website, shown in URLs starting with “https://” and a lock icon.
  • ID number – A unique identification number given to a person by the government, such as an identity card or passport.
  • Information disorder – A general term for different types of false or harmful information, including misinformation, disinformation, and malinformation.
  • Malicious link – A web link that leads to harmful content such as malware, fake login pages, or sites designed to steal your information.
  • Malinformation – True information shared out of context or with harmful intent.
  • Malware – Harmful software designed to damage devices, steal information, or gain unauthorised access.
  • Misinformation – False or misleading information shared without the intention to deceive.
  • Password manager – A secure application that stores and organises your passwords, and can generate strong new ones.
  • Phishing – When someone pretends to be a trusted person or organisation to trick you into giving personal information such as passwords, phone numbers, or bank details.
  • Privacy policy – A statement on a website explaining how your personal data is collected, used, and protected.
  • Privacy settings – Controls on social media platforms that let you decide who can see your posts, photos, and personal information.
  • Propaganda – Systematic spreading of biased or misleading information to influence public opinion.
  • Public profile – A profile where posts and personal information are visible to anyone, even people who are not your friends or followers.
  • Reverse image search – A tool that lets you upload or paste a picture to find where it appears on the internet, helping to check if a photo is original or stolen.
  • Romance scam – A type of scam where someone pretends to have romantic feelings to build trust and then asks for money, gifts, or personal information.
  • Scam – A deceptive scheme designed to cheat people out of money, personal data, or other valuables.
  • Secure URL – A website address that begins with “https://”, showing it uses encryption to keep your information private.
  • Shortened link – A web link made shorter using services like bit.ly; it hides the full address and can sometimes be used to trick people.
  • Social engineering – Tricks and psychological tactics used by scammers to manipulate people into giving away personal information or access.
  • Troll / Trolling – Provocative or harmful behaviour online intended to disrupt or create conflict.
  • Two-factor authentication (2FA) – An extra security step that requires not only your password but also another code (for example, sent to your phone) to log in.
  • URL – The web address of a site (e.g., https://www.example.com).
  • Virtual background – A digital image or effect that hides your real surroundings during a video call.
